snippet.textDisplay: I am aware that Bulleh Shah is a famous Sufi poet whose love poems probably had spiritual underpinnings. But when taken out of context in this manner and staged with a heavy metal guitar backdrop, that aspect of Shah's poetry doesn't exactly communicate.  And the Aerosmith Effect is positively discordant when paired with the deeply meditative rapture of the Durga Stotram.
snippet.textOriginal: I am aware that Bulleh Shah is a famous Sufi poet whose love poems probably had spiritual underpinnings. But when taken out of context in this manner and staged with a heavy metal guitar backdrop, that aspect of Shah's poetry doesn't exactly communicate.  And the Aerosmith Effect is positively discordant when paired with the deeply meditative rapture of the Durga Stotram.

snippet.textDisplay: Just in case some of you interpret my objection to this as Puritanism -- let me clarify that I'm all for creativity but not in a way that shows complete ignorance of the meaning and context of sacred works that have a deep significance for those who comprehend them.
snippet.textOriginal: Just in case some of you interpret my objection to this as Puritanism -- let me clarify that I'm all for creativity but not in a way that shows complete ignorance of the meaning and context of sacred works that have a deep significance for those who comprehend them.

snippet.textDisplay:
The introductory text under the clip begins : "This song celebrates one of India's Greatest mythological Super Heroes -- Durga in the form Mahishasura Mardini." Durga, a "Mythological super hero?"  Doubtless India's answer to Cat Woman and Supergirl ?
Who gets to write this stuff, and how does it get by unchallenged and uncorrected in a supposedly Hindu majority country?
snippet.textOriginal:
The introductory text under the clip begins : "This song celebrates one of India's Greatest mythological Super Heroes -- Durga in the form Mahishasura Mardini." Durga, a "Mythological super hero?"  Doubtless India's answer to Cat Woman and Supergirl ?
Who gets to write this stuff, and how does it get by unchallenged and uncorrected in a supposedly Hindu majority country?

snippet.textDisplay: With all due respect for artistic freedom, this piece is grotesque and disrespectful. To pair Adi Sankara's exquisite slokas worshiping Durga with lyrics describing a woman's physical longing for her lover is an abomination. I am hoping Aruna S participated because she did not understand the other lyrics. Hindus don't have to behave like the Taliban, but they can show some spine. Can you imagine a Led Zeppelin version of "Silent Night" or Handel's "Messiah" paired with a Madonna song?
snippet.textOriginal: With all due respect for artistic freedom, this piece is grotesque and disrespectful. To pair Adi Sankara's exquisite slokas worshiping Durga with lyrics describing a woman's physical longing for her lover is an abomination. I am hoping Aruna S participated because she did not understand the other lyrics. Hindus don't have to behave like the Taliban, but they can show some spine. Can you imagine a Led Zeppelin version of "Silent Night" or Handel's "Messiah" paired with a Madonna song?

snippet.textDisplay: At this rate, you will possibly call Narsinh Mehta a transgender writer of soft porn. There are many strings to the veena of the love of God. Distinctions are made by people who cannot see the whole. I would not call them mean of spirit, but they seem to be quite limited. I am sure Adi Shankara would have no objection.  Bulle Shah might not have Adi Shankaras' stature and renown, but when did the Great Listener ever ask for our pedigree? Open up your mind.
snippet.textOriginal: At this rate, you will possibly call Narsinh Mehta a transgender writer of soft porn. There are many strings to the veena of the love of God. Distinctions are made by people who cannot see the whole. I would not call them mean of spirit, but they seem to be quite limited. I am sure Adi Shankara would have no objection.  Bulle Shah might not have Adi Shankaras' stature and renown, but when did the Great Listener ever ask for our pedigree? Open up your mind.

snippet.textDisplay: Everything fine but where does this "liberalized Indians" bit come from and what does this have to do with this track? I objected to the mating of this hymn to Ishq Nachaya for the reasons I mentioned in my other posts. But,I am a liberalised person. I am not religious. I do not believe in god.I still objected to this track.I respect your right to believe in god and religion.Let us not politicise everything with half-baked, ill conceived understanding of what is liberal and what is conservative.

snippet.textDisplay:
'Tere Ishq Nachaya' is actually a sufi rendition of a 'bhakt' for his murshid. In this case, Bulleh Shah is writing about his murshid Sheikh Farid.

Nevertheless, I completely, totally, agree with you that trying to fuse these two genre is like trying to mix oil and water.
snippet.textOriginal:
'Tere Ishq Nachaya' is actually a sufi rendition of a 'bhakt' for his murshid. In this case, Bulleh Shah is writing about his murshid Sheikh Farid.

Nevertheless, I completely, totally, agree with you that trying to fuse these two genre is like trying to mix oil and water.

snippet.textDisplay: I just had a funny thought.... The first Aigiri Nandini is when Durga Devi appears to kill Mahishasura and all the devas pray to her saying, "Jaya Jaya" (May you be victorious) and so she blesses them and goes to Mahishasura. He sees her and drools over her and says , "tere Ishq Nachaya" :D and Durga Devi gets so enraged at his "Thaiya Thaiya" that she kills him there itself. The gods are happy and again start singing, "Aigiri Nandini Nandita Medini Vishwavinodini Nandinute..." :p How is it? :D
snippet.textOriginal: I just had a funny thought.... The first Aigiri Nandini is when Durga Devi appears to kill Mahishasura and all the devas pray to her saying, "Jaya Jaya" (May you be victorious) and so she blesses them and goes to Mahishasura. He sees her and drools over her and says , "tere Ishq Nachaya" :D and Durga Devi gets so enraged at his "Thaiya Thaiya" that she kills him there itself. snippet.textDisplay:
Comment - 2 - 
If any of those care for knowing the meaning and intention of those lines, they would have searched it and found that indeed the word "Ishq" and the related ones are toward "Divine love" of a disciple(Baba Bulle shah) for his master, as opposed to the stereotypical "love" portrayed in movies, and hence the Sufi lines are in perfect sync with the religious Sanskrit shloka.
snippet.textOriginal:
Comment - 2 - 
If any of those care for knowing the meaning and intention of those lines, they would have searched it and found that indeed the word "Ishq" and the related ones are toward "Divine love" of a disciple(Baba Bulle shah) for his master, as opposed to the stereotypical "love" portrayed in movies, and hence the Sufi lines are in perfect sync with the religious Sanskrit shloka.

snippet.textDisplay: Shivam Limaye, I am not complaining about the music alone.A musical composition does not stand on its ability to appeal only to the ear.It is a combination of the lyric too that appeals to your intellectual and emotional senses.You tell me how Aigiri Nandini,a deeply devotional hymn,praising mother goddess can be mated to Tere Ishq nachaya?I am not talking about religious sentiments.There has to be harmony and connectivity between the themes too.Anyway one man's mead is another man's poison.
snippet.textOriginal: Shivam Limaye, I am not complaining about the music alone.A musical composition does not stand on its ability to appeal only to the ear.It is a combination of the lyric too that appeals to your intellectual and emotional senses.You tell me how Aigiri Nandini,a deeply devotional hymn,praising mother goddess can be mated to Tere Ishq nachaya?I am not talking about religious sentiments.There has to be harmony and connectivity between the themes too.Anyway one man's mead is another man's poison.

snippet.textDisplay:
I don't get it. 

Aigiri Nandini is a prayer to Goddess Durga. Aruni Sairam is singing about the one who slayed the great demons (Mahishasura mardhini). Then Ram Sampath kicks in with a dark, sorta metal riffs to make this sound more menacing. Then lead guitar morphs into a tangential carnatic path. Later Sona M enters to tell her lover to come back in some Punjabi dialect. Backing vocals going Thaiya thaiya (??) and we merge back to the start. 

How the fuck is this fusion working? Thumbs down
snippet.textOriginal:
I don't get it. 

Aigiri Nandini is a prayer to Goddess Durga. Aruni Sairam is singing about the one who slayed the great demons (Mahishasura mardhini). Then Ram Sampath kicks in with a dark, sorta metal riffs to make this sound more menacing. Then lead guitar morphs into a tangential carnatic path. Later Sona M enters to tell her lover to come back in some Punjabi dialect. Backing vocals going Thaiya thaiya (??) and we merge back to the start. 

How the fuck is this fusion working? Thumbs down

snippet.textDisplay: Love the progressive structure of the composition. Nirdosh sobti u genius ... Wonderful rhythm guitars , also love the groove and rhythm guitars . This is niche music ... Bits of it reminded me of the golden era of prog-rock ... Thanks Ram Sampath for bringing magic here ...

snippet.textDisplay: Guys I feel instead of fighting over the amalgamation we should really enjoy the mix and if you really relate it to the mahishasura story the tere ishq ne nachaya part fits well where goddess Kali is dancing and calling out to Mahadev, so that he can come and get her back in her original avtar of Parvati.... Thats my take on this beautiful mix.....
